heading: MERGE CONFLICTS
des: STEP 1: OPEN UP files having merge conflicts STEP 2: REMOVE the conflicts      OPTION 1: ACCEPT INCOMING CHANGES      OPTION 2: ACCEPT CURRENT CHANGES      OPTION 3: ACCEPT BOTH CHANGES      OPTION 4: COMPARE CHANGES STEP 3: REMOVE the conflict markers STEP 4: STAGE and COMMIT the changes

subHead.head: 1. BUILD A NEW REPOSITORY AND START WORKING FROM SCRATCH (BY REMOTING)

data.des: STEP 1: CREATE A NEW REPOSITORY ON YOUR GITHUB WEBSITE AND COPY THE URL STEP 2: CREATES an empty git repository
STEP 3: WRITE YOUR PIECE OF CODE STEP 4: a commit is needed to push any files to github
STEP 5: CREATES a new REMOTE DESTINATION for the github repository
LOGS out the REMOTE URL if any
STEP 6: PUSHES the last commited code to github p.s. the -u is like a setting the origin remote and master branch as a default so that we can use just >> git push in future

data.des: STEP 1: CREATE A NEW REPOSITORY ON YOUR GITHUB WEBSITE AND COPY THE URL STEP 2: CLONES as well as automatically sets the REMOTE DESTINATION
STEP 3: WRITE YOUR PIECE OF CODE STEP 4: a commit is needed to push any files to github
STEP 5: PUSHES the last commited code to github

Origin/Master is called as a Remote Tracking Branch, it is a Remote Branch that represents our Local Branch. 

 LOGS the remote tracking branch

To CHECK the remote branch code. 
 DETACHES HEAD onto the remote tracking HEAD, in a case where the local branch is ahead of the remote branch and not up to date, push to make it up to date

By default only Local Master Branch is connected to the Remote Tracking Branch but others need to be connected in order to work with them and the simplest way to do so is.. 

 To CHECK all the branches available
This automatically CONNECTS the two branches and we can freely work on them now
Now this correctly LOGS all the connected branches

FETCHING allows to get changes from the Github Remote Repository to our Local Git Repository but doesn't change into the Working Directory 

 To RECIEVE or FETCH the new commits

CREATES a new branch having the changes but this doesnt interfere in the working directory. 
 the origin/master now heads on to this new branch and the master branch would be one branch behind the origin/master

To  CHECK the remote branch code. 
 DETACHES HEAD onto the remote tracking HEAD, in a case where the local branch is ahead of the remote branch and not up to date, push to make it up to date

PULLING = FETCHING + MERGING 
 PULLS the changes and merges the changes with the branch you want to OR default
This will DELETE your previous commits and push your current one. f signifies force
This is nothing but FETCH + REBASE. This will invoke rebase in interactive mode where you can choose how to apply each individual commit that isn't in the history you are rebasing on

heading: GITHUB COLLABORATION
des: CENTRALIZED WORKFLOW: EVERY BODY WORKS ON THE SAME MAIN BRANCH AND PUSH AND PULL IN THE MAIN BRANCH ONLY. FEATURE BRANCH WORKFLOW: EVERY FEATURE IS PUSHED UPON ANOTHER INDEPENDANT BRANCH TO MINIMIZE MESS GITHUB PULL REQUEST WORKFLOW: Once a pull request is opened, you can discuss and review the potential changes with collaborators and add follow-up commits before your changes are merged into the base branch. GITHUB FORKS AND CLONE WORKFLOW: Forking nd then opening a pull request to the owner of the main repository.

heading: GITHUB DESKTOP
des: STEP 1: Download GitHub Desktop for Windows STEP 2: Click on “File” on the navbar, go down to “Options,” choose “Accounts,” and get authentication STEP 3: You can create a new repository by selecting the File menu and clicking New repository. STEP 4: You can add a repository from your local computer by selecting the File menu and clicking Add Local Repository. STEP 5: You can clone a repository from GitHub by selecting the File menu and clicking Clone Repository. STEP 6: You can use GitHub Desktop to create a branch of a project. STEP 7: After you make changes to a branch, you can review them in GitHub Desktop and make a commit to keep track of your changes. STEP 8: You can use GitHub Desktop to create issues or pull requests to collaborate on projects with other people. STEP 9: When you make changes to your local repositories or when other people make changes to the remote repositories, you will need to sync your local copy of the project with the remote repository.
